Package edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.logic

Class Conditional<E extends Expression>

java.lang.Object
edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.logic.Conditional<E>
Type Parameters:
E - the type of expression of this conditional's condition; this type must be compatible with true, since the last condition of every conditional is implicitly true
All Implemented Interfaces:
Expression, Logical, Simplifiable, Typed, Serializable, Comparable<Logical>
public class Conditional<E extends Expression> extends Object implements Expression
A conditional is a logical expression which can have one of several possible values depending on which of its Boolean conditions evaluates to true. A conditional defines some number of condition/branch pairs. Conditions must be of type boolean, but branches can be of any type. The first condition is paired with the first branch, the second condition with the second branch, and so on. A conditional evaluates its conditions in order; once a condition which evaluates to true is found, the corresponding branch is evaluated and that value returned. There should always be exactly one more branch than condition; the condition for the last branch is implicitly true in order to ensure that some condition will always hold. A conditional can be thought of as an if / else if ... / else statement in a programming language where the else branch is mandatory.

A trivial conditional has zero conditions and one branch (whose condition is implicitly true). A trivial conditional is logically equivalent to its only branch.

The return value of Expression.toValued() is a conditional whose conditions are in disjunctive normal form and whose branches are valued expressions. A conditional is not a valued expression, but removing conditionals from inside an expression and converting it to potentially many branches is an important step in converting an expression to a valued expression. The Expression.toValued() method of expressions which do not contain any conditionals should return a trivial conditional.

When a conditional effect is converted to disjunctive normal form as a precondition the ordering of the conditions may no longer be enforced, so the conditions are serialized. This means the first condition is unchanged, but the second condition includes a negation of the first condition, and the third condition includes a negation of the first and second conditions, etc. The same is true when converting to disjunctive normal form as an effect, since the conditional will becomes a series of conditional effects whose order can no longer be enforced; the conditions will be serialized to preserve the effects of the original ordering of the conditions.

Author:
Stephen G. Ware

  • Constructor Details

    • Conditional

      public Conditional(ImmutableArray<E> conditions, ImmutableArray<Expression> branches)
      Constructs a new conditional with the given immutable arrays of conditions and branches.
      Parameters:
      conditions - the Boolean conditions, in the order they should be evaluated
      branches - exactly one more branch than conditions, where the first branch is paired with the first condition, the second branch with the second condition, etc., and the last branch implicitly has a condition of true
      Throws:
      FormatException - if any condition is not of type boolean
      FormatException - if the number of branches is not exactly the number of conditions plus one

    • Conditional

      branches - the branches

      Applies a given function to every part of this logical formula and then creates a new logical formula of this same type using the results returned from the function. If, for every part of this formula, the function always returns its input as output with no changes, this method should return this object (not just any object that is equal to this object).

    • evaluate

      public Value evaluate(State state)
      Evaluates each condition in order until one of them evaluates to true, and then evaluates the branch corresponding to that condition and returns that value. Because the last branch implicitly has a condition of true, some branch will always be evaluated. Evaluation of conditions is short circuiting, meaning that once a condition evaluates to true, evaluation of conditions will stop.
      Specified by:
      evaluate in interface Expression
      Parameters:
      state - the state in which this conditional will be evaluated
      Returns:
      the value of the branch corresponding to the true condition

    • toValued

      public Conditional<Disjunction<Clause<Precondition>>> toValued()
      Description copied from interface: Expression
      Returns a conditional expression whose conditions are in disjunctive normal form and whose branches are valued expressions. This method is used to simplify expressions by converting anything which is not valued into valued expressions and moving any conditionals outside of the expression. If the expression is already valued, the conditional returned should have no conditions and a single branch that is this expression.
      Specified by:
      toValued in interface Expression
      Returns:
      a conditional with conditions in disjunctive normal form and branches that are valued expressions

    • toPrecondition

      public Disjunction<Clause<Precondition>> toPrecondition()
      Converts this conditional expression to disjunctive normal form, but since the order of conditions may no longer be enforced in the resulting disjunction, the conditions are serialized. This means the second condition includes a negation of the first condition, the third condition includes a negation of the first and second conditions, and so on.
      Specified by:
      toPrecondition in interface Expression
      Returns:
      a disjunction of conjunctive clauses whose atoms are preconditions

    • toEffect

      public Clause<Effect> toEffect()
      Converts this conditional expression to disjunctive normal form, but since the order of conditions may no longer be forced in the resulting clause, the conditions are serialized. This means the second condition includes a negation of the first condition, the third condition includes a negation of the first and second conditions, and so on.
      Specified by:
      toEffect in interface Expression
      Returns:
      a conjunctive clause whose atoms are effects
